text: Racial capitalism begins with a simple but unsettling idea: inequality is not a flaw in capitalist systems, but one of their engines.

text: The creation of wealth for some requires the exploitation of others, and throughout history those “others” have been defined along racial lines.
tree: (TOP (S (S (NP (NP (DT DT) (NN NN)) (PP (IN IN) (NP (NN NN))) (PP (IN IN) (NP (DT DT)))) (VP (VBZ VBZ) (NP (NP (DT DT) (NN NN)) (PP (IN IN) (NP (NNS NNS)))))) (, ,) (CC CC) (S (PP (IN IN) (NP (NN NN))) (NP (DT DT) (`` ``) (NNS NNS) ('' '')) (VP (VBP VBP) (VP (VBN VBN) (VP (VBN VBN) (PP (IN IN) (NP (JJ JJ) (NNS NNS))))))) (. .)))

text: Race became a tool for sorting human beings into categories of economic value — who would profit, who would labor, who would be controlled, who would be discarded.

text: The consequences of this arrangement have shaped centuries of social reality, and they continue to define everyday life in ways that are easy to overlook because they have been so thoroughly normalized.
tree: (TOP (S (S (NP (NP (DT DT) (NNS NNS)) (PP (IN IN) (NP (DT DT) (NN NN)))) (VP (VBP VBP) (VP (VBN VBN) (NP (NP (NNS NNS)) (PP (IN IN) (NP (JJ JJ) (NN NN))))))) (, ,) (CC CC) (S (NP (PRP PRP)) (VP (VBP VBP) (S (VP (TO TO) (VP (VB VB) (NP (JJ JJ) (NN NN)) (PP (IN IN) (NP (NP (NNS NNS)) (SBAR (WHNP (WDT WDT)) (S (VP (VBP VBP) (ADJP (JJ JJ) (SBAR (S (VP (TO TO) (VP (VB VB)))))) (SBAR (IN IN) (S (NP (PRP PRP)) (VP (VBP VBP) (VP (VBN VBN) (ADVP (RB RB) (RB RB)) (VP (VBN VBN)))))))))))))))) (. .)))

text: When you examine the history closely, capitalism’s growth is inseparable from the commodification of racialized groups.
tree: (TOP (S (SBAR (WHADVP (WRB WRB)) (S (NP (PRP PRP)) (VP (VBP VBP) (NP (DT DT) (NN NN)) (ADVP (RB RB))))) (, ,) (NP (NP (NN NN) (POS POS) (POS POS)) (NN NN)) (VP (VBZ VBZ) (ADJP (JJ JJ) (PP (IN IN) (NP (NP (DT DT) (NN NN)) (PP (IN IN) (NP (VBN VBN) (NNS NNS))))))) (. .)))

text: And the institutions that claim to study human behavior and society — history, science, psychology — have often worked to reinforce rather than challenge these structures.

text: To understand racial capitalism, we have to begin with power.

text: Capitalism concentrates power in the hands of those who own and control resources.

text: In a fair system, economic mobility would allow anyone to rise through effort and innovation.

text: But history shows that the playing field was uneven long before the game began.
tree: (TOP (S (CC CC) (NP (NN NN)) (VP (VBZ VBZ) (SBAR (IN IN) (S (NP (DT DT) (NN NN) (NN NN)) (VP (VBD VBD) (ADJP (JJ JJ)) (SBAR (ADVP (RB RB)) (IN IN) (S (NP (DT DT) (NN NN)) (VP (VBD VBD)))))))) (. .)))

text: Slavery, colonial extraction, segregation, discriminatory policy, and policing did more than limit opportunity — they generated enormous wealth for those at the top while structurally withholding it from those at the bottom.

text: After the end of slavery, the Thirteenth Amendment famously prohibited forced labor — except as punishment for a crime.

text: That loophole was not an oversight.

text: It created a direct pathway for slavery to continue in a new form.

text: Black Americans, newly freed from plantation labor, were arrested on vague charges like vagrancy or “suspicious behavior,” then leased out to corporations and industries that needed cheap labor.

text: Incarceration became profitable, and Black bodies once again became instruments of economic expansion.

text: The racial hierarchy had not disappeared; it had simply adapted to the legal system of a capitalist democracy.

text: The pattern repeated itself years later under the banner of “law and order.” Harsh drug policies punished heavily in the communities least protected from poverty and systemic neglect.

text: The justification, framed as science and public safety, masked an economic logic: prisons filled, private contracts expanded, police departments gained funding, municipalities collected fines.

text: Inequality was not incidental; it was profitable.

text: In cities like Ferguson, Missouri, minor infractions — jaywalking, a broken tail light, missing paperwork — became opportunities for local governments to extract money from residents, who were disproportionately Black and poor.

text: The wealth of modern capitalism does not appear as the reward of innovation alone, but as the accumulated profit of extraction and exclusion.

text: Liberation Psychology takes a similar turn in a different field.

text: Instead of treating individuals as isolated minds with internal disorders, it examines how social structures harm mental wellbeing.
tree: (TOP (S (PP (RB RB) (IN IN) (S (VP (VBG VBG) (NP (NNS NNS)) (PP (IN IN) (NP (NP (JJ JJ) (NNS NNS)) (PP (IN IN) (NP (JJ JJ) (NNS NNS)))))))) (, ,) (NP (PRP PRP)) (VP (VBZ VBZ) (SBAR (WHADVP (WRB WRB)) (S (NP (JJ JJ) (NNS NNS)) (VP (VBP VBP) (NP (JJ JJ) (NN NN)))))) (. .)))

text: It recognizes that trauma, stress, and psychological suffering often stem from inequality — and that healing involves changing those systems, not forcing individuals to adapt to them.

text: Where traditional psychology asked how to help marginalized people function within oppressive realities, liberation psychology asks how to dismantle the oppression itself.

text: These approaches flip the script.
tree: (TOP (S (NP (DT DT) (NNS NNS)) (VP (VBP VBP) (NP (DT DT) (NN NN))) (. .)))

text: They say that the perspective of the oppressed is not an alternative version of the story; it is the truth that the dominant narrative worked to bury.

text: Understanding racial capitalism is not only about history.

text: It’s about recognizing how current systems continue to operate on the same principles.

text: We also need to understand that racism adapts.

text: It appears through economic policies, scientific claims, and cultural norms that feel “neutral” but produce racially unequal outcomes.

text: That is what makes racial capitalism so persistent.
tree: (TOP (S (NP (DT DT)) (VP (VBZ VBZ) (SBAR (WHNP (WP WP)) (S (VP (VBZ VBZ) (S (NP (JJ JJ) (NN NN)) (ADJP (RB RB) (JJ JJ))))))) (. .)))

text: It hides its exploitation behind the appearance of fairness.

text: It convinces society that success is simply a matter of effort, even when the ground is tilted so steeply that climbing is nearly impossible for some and effortless for others.

text: Liberation psychology emphasizes collective action over individual coping, helping people recognize that their struggles are not evidence of personal failure but symptoms of unjust systems.

text: History from Below encourages students — the future leaders and voters and policymakers — to see that the world they accept today was created by human decisions, and human decisions can change it.

text: Still, awareness is only the first step.

text: Racial capitalism is deeply rooted, fueled by laws, profit structures, media narratives, and even the subconscious assumptions we inherit from the world around us.

text: There is no single policy that will undo its effects, no brief period of reform that will erase centuries of exploitation.

text: If society continues to learn history only from the perspective of conquerors and capitalism only from the perspective of beneficiaries, the injustice will stay invisible.
tree: (TOP (S (SBAR (IN IN) (S (NP (NN NN)) (VP (VBZ VBZ) (S (VP (TO TO) (VP (VB VB) (NP (NN NN)) (PP (ADVP (RB RB)) (IN IN) (NP (NP (DT DT) (NN NN)) (PP (IN IN) (NP (NNS NNS)))) (CC CC) (NP (NN NN)) (PP (ADVP (RB RB)) (IN IN) (NP (NP (DT DT) (NN NN)) (PP (IN IN) (NP (NNS NNS)))))))))))) (, ,) (NP (DT DT) (NN NN)) (VP (MD MD) (VP (VB VB) (ADJP (JJ JJ)))) (. .)))

text: The question, ultimately, is what kind of world we want to build.

text: A system that requires some people to remain vulnerable for others to feel secure is not sustainable.

text: A form of prosperity that depends on the suffering of others cannot be considered progress.

text: If we believe that human beings deserve dignity, opportunity, and autonomy, then we need an economic system that reflects those values.

text: That requires re-examining the foundations rather than patching up the visible cracks.

text: Racial capitalism teaches us that inequality is not an accident — it is a design.

text: Psychology’s role must be to support that process, not obstruct it.

text: And recognizing that systems are human creations gives us the responsibility to build something better.
